1003044600 POST AND TIMES STAR Cincinnati, Ohio October 26, 1961
Tobacco Research Grants Approved
NEW YORK (UPI): Timothy V. Hartnett, chairman of the Tobacco Industry Research Colinmittee, has announced 30 research grants, totaling more than $296,000, to inde- pendent scientists in 14 states for studies relating to tobacco use and health.
Fifteen of the grants are for new research projects and the remainder for continued investigation into a wide range of subjects, said Dr. Clarence Cook " Little, scien- tific director of the TIRC.
The committee, Hartnett said, has appropriated a to- tal of $4,650,000 thus far for research.
1003044600
BALTIMORE MORNING SUN Baltimore, Maryland October 27, 1961
Two Hopkins Doctors Get Tobacco Grants
Dr. Caroline B. Thomas and Dr. George O. Gey, both associ- ated with the Johns Hopkins Uni- versity, have been awarded re- search grants by the Tobacco In- dustry Research Committee. The grants are for research projects already under way.
Theirs: are among 30 research grants, totaling over $296,000, that have been awarded to independ- ent scientists by the tobacco in- dustry for studies relating to tobacco use and health.
1003044600 A
NEW YORK JOURNAL-AMERICAN New York, New York October 25, 1961
New Tobacco Grants Made
Thirty research grants, tot- aling over $296,000. to scien- tists in 14 states for studies relating to tobacco use and .health. were announced today by Timothy V. Hartnett. chair- man of the Tobacco Industry Research Committee.
The new grants make a tota: of 154 initial grants and 172 renewals awarded to scientists in some 75 institutions. Ali are made by an advisory board of independent doctors and scientists, which direct the T.I.R.C.'s research program. T.I.R.C. has appropriatedi $4 .- 650,000 for research to date.
Fifteen of the grants an- nounced today are for new research projects, the others for continuation of inves- tigations over a wide range of subjects according to D :. Clarence Cook Little, Scientific Director of the T.I.R.C.
1003044600 D
WORLD-TELEGRAM AND SUN New York, New York October 25, 1961
Tobacco-Health Grants Allotted
Thirty research grants, total. ing over $296,000, to independ- ent scientists in 14 states for studies relating to tabacco use and health, were announced' today by Timonthy V. Hart- nett, chairman of the Tobacco Industry Research Committee. The new grants make a total of 134 initial grants and 172 renewals awarded to scientists in some 75 institutions.
CHICAGO SUN-TIMES Chicago, Illinois October 23, 1961
NU Professor Given Tobacco Research Grant
Special to The Sun-Tiines NEW YORK -Dr. Robert W. Hull, assistant professor of biology at Northwestern Uni- versity, has been awarded a re- search grant from the Tobacco Industry Research Committee. it was announced Sunday:
For the last six months. Dr. Hull has been searching for a scientific test that will rapidly determine the kind and concen- tration of combustion products that in tests have caused cancer among mice. R
The current test takes 6 to 18 months. Dr. Hull hopes that a new technique can reduce the test to a few days duration.
Dr. Hull's grant is one of 30 more research grants, totaling more than $296,000, that have been awarded by the committee to: independent scientists in 14 states for studies relating to to- bacco use and health.
1003044600 B
1003044600 E
IOWAN Iowa City, Iowa October 26, 1961
TOBACCO STUDY
Dr. J. P. Lung of SUI has been awarded a research grant by the Tobacco Industry Research com- mittee to conduct studies on the , cardiovascular properties of nico- tine.
Long, associate " professor of. pharmacology, received one of 30 research grants for study relating to tobacco use and health.
C
For the T.I.R.C. grants, both general and localized news releases were sent out.

NEW YORK (UPI): Timothy V. Hartnett, chairman of the Tobacco Industry Research Colinmittee, has announced 30 research grants, totaling more than $296,000, to inde- pendent scientists in 14 states for studies relating to tobacco use and health.
Fifteen of the grants are for new research projects and the remainder for continued investigation into a wide range of subjects, said Dr. Clarence Cook " Little, scien- tific director of the TIRC.
The committee, Hartnett said, has appropriated a to- tal of $4,650,000 thus far for research.

Theirs: are among 30 research grants, totaling over $296,000, that have been awarded to independ- ent scientists by the tobacco in- dustry for studies relating to tobacco use and health.
NEW YORK JOURNAL-AMERICAN New York, New York October 25, 1961
New Tobacco Grants Made

Thirty research grants, tot- aling over $296,000. to scien- tists in 14 states for studies relating to tobacco use and .health. were announced today by Timothy V. Hartnett. chair- man of the Tobacco Industry Research Committee.

The new grants make a tota: of 154 initial grants and 172 renewals awarded to scientists in some 75 institutions. Ali are made by an advisory board of independent doctors and scientists, which direct the T.I.R.C.'s research program. T.I.R.C. has appropriatedi $4 .- 650,000 for research to date.

Fifteen of the grants an- nounced today are for new research projects, the others for continuation of inves- tigations over a wide range of subjects according to D :. Clarence Cook Little, Scientific Director of the T.I.R.C.

Special to The Sun-Tiines NEW YORK -Dr. Robert W. Hull, assistant professor of biology at Northwestern Uni- versity, has been awarded a re- search grant from the Tobacco Industry Research Committee. it was announced Sunday:

For the last six months. Dr. Hull has been searching for a scientific test that will rapidly determine the kind and concen- tration of combustion products that in tests have caused cancer among mice. R
The current test takes 6 to 18 months. Dr. Hull hopes that a new technique can reduce the test to a few days duration.

Dr. Hull's grant is one of 30 more research grants, totaling more than $296,000, that have been awarded by the committee to: independent scientists in 14 states for studies relating to to- bacco use and health.
